Arief

If you have a existing flame object ("flame") that you have just
completed a solution you can change the boundary conditions (T,Y)
through the 
"flame.burner" object:
flame.burner.set(massflux = mdot, mole_fractions = X, temperature = T
)

And the operating pressure through the "flame" object:
flame.setPressure(p)

and solve for a new solution:
flame.solve(loglevel,refine_grid)

Alternatively, if you have a solution that you previously saved to an
xml file using the
command:
   flame.save('flame.xml', id = 'firstBC' ).  

, you can load the solution into  another flame object or the same
using the
commands:
   flame2.init()
   flame2.restore('flame.xml', id = 'firstBC')

And then change the boundary and operating conditions of this flame
object ("flame2") using
the "set" commands as above. 


Hope this works.  

Dave Huckaby

>>> ae.dahoe@... 5/23/2005 7:33:37 AM >>>

Dear Dave,

Suppose that I have a laminar flame solution
at a particular combination of (p,T,phi,Y1..Yn).
How can I use this solution at an initial
guess to compute the flame structure at
different (p,T,phi,Y1..Yn) conditions?
Does mfluxie also belong to this set?

Arief
